captions.text:
Hey, now that the post apocalypse is starting
to feel less like an overused setting in fiction

and more like a fucking dress rehearsal, wanna
play a game about small furry animals retaking

the Earth after the human race dies out? Well
then play Tokyo Jungle, genius, it&#39;s got cute

pomeranians ripping the throats out of bunny
rabbits, and what kind of monster can&#39;t find

joy in that. I guess there&#39;s Biomutant now
too but you don&#39;t get to be a pomeranian in

that so I don&#39;t know how it had the balls
to show its face. Actually that does raise

the awkward question of what the fuck kind
of animal we ARE playing in Biomutant. Best

guess, a sort of hyena cat leopard raccoon
lemur sloth. Like we were conceived at the

Lion King wrap party and nobody was willing
to claim parentage. Anyway, Biomutant is an

RPG, and you know what that means. Stats,
stats, stattety stats. Character creation

time, let&#39;s randomly combine seven zoo animals
to create your physical appearance and then

choose our favourite stat. I hate when a game
forces me to make a whole bunch of character

building decisions before I know the first
fucking thing about the game. Do you want

to put points into intelligence? I don&#39;t know,
do I.

I mean, how much intelligence does it generally
take to hold a big knife by the non-ouchy

part and stick it in everything softer than
a tree trunk? What about charisma? It makes

it easier to pass persuasion checks! But how
often does that come up? Is this one of those

RPGs where high charisma is the secret easy
mode or one where any build not specced for

combat is going to get chumped like a concerned
parent at an after school knife fighting club?

Spoiler alert, it&#39;s the second one. Biomutant
is an open world RPG that&#39;s trying to do a

lot of things, none of them well. This is
normally the point where I&#39;d summarise the

story, and I assume the game has one in the
sense that I assume a teenager&#39;s bedroom has

or at one point had a floor. What certainly
doesn&#39;t help is the slightly insane decision

to have the narrator be the only one capable
of speaking. Every character you interact

with only talks in animalistic grumbles like
dogs upset that you stopped rubbing their

tummy and so the narrator has to summarise
what they&#39;re saying, and this is an RPG, you

talk to characters all the time. It creates
the vibe that we&#39;re experiencing the story
second hand.

Grumble grumble whine whine. &quot;He says you
are this kingdom&#39;s only hope, brave adventurer,

and his tone of voice was assuredly very inspiring.&quot;
This isn&#39;t the story, this is the fucking

Cliff notes. But even if they&#39;d gotten in
the fucking Royal Shakespeare Company, it

wouldn&#39;t help, &#39;cos the plot comes at you
like a two foot high sandwich to an unprepared

jaw. You start off in a bunker and then you
rescue a dude from some standard enemies and

he informs you that your parents and home
village were murdered by a monstrous villain

and you want revenge. Oh thank you for jogging
my memory, you know how these things slip

my mind. Except I don&#39;t think that&#39;s actually
the plot. The plot seems to be, you have been

volunteered to save the world by restoring
the Tree of Life. Or possibly by destroying

the Tree of Life. Oh yes, we have to pick
a path on the ever unsubtle black and white

moral spectrum where the choice is either
friendship and hugs or violence and powerbombs

and every single fucking character in the
game feels entitled to judge you on which

path you&#39;re heading down. That is, assuming
the narrator is to be believed. They might

all be taking the piss out of my eyepatch
for all I know. So the Tree of Life is important

somehow, and it has four roots and the one
to the west is being ravaged by the evil Fluffy
Muffy.

But Pongo is building a Nutbanger device that
you can use to wrongle the binkybonk before

going to the second root in the north which
is being splatplopped by the nickynackynoo.

Hold the fuck up. Your story, Biomutant, could
at least have the decency to buy me dinner

before it spooges all of itself over my face
at once. So absorbing the story in Biomutant

is like trying to translate a badly written
message on the top of a speeding custard pie

that&#39;s being thrown at someone else. But what
do you actually do in the game? Well, it&#39;s

an open world RPG, so usually what you do
is go to where the icon says to go, where

some kind of sentient hedgehog otter weasel
thing will give you a mech suit and tell you

to use it to gather five squeaky ducks that
you can use in the next boss fight to win

somehow and you know what I&#39;m just going to
stop trying to get my head around all this.

Another thing you&#39;re obliged to do is take
over territories for your tribe, which ties

into the moral choice thing because at the
start you have to choose whether to side with

the tribe that wants you to murder all its
enemies and let the world burn in chaos or

the side that wants you to murder all its
enemies and then get all judgey at you about
it.

Obviously I went with the second lot because
I&#39;m not fucking fifteen, and then just before

every stronghold takeover mission your dudes
are all like &quot;Try to avoid violence!&quot; And

I&#39;m like &quot;Well tell that to the fucking mission
because as soon as I kick the door in it&#39;s

going to spawn a bunch of lads and tell me
to defeat them to proceed.&quot; &quot;Oh you can go

to fucking town on them, I just meant violence
against people who count.&quot; Yeah, so it&#39;s only

when you confront the leader of a stronghold
that you have the option to try to persuade

them to give up without a fight. Which is
the only place where the charisma build comes

into things. So I wouldn&#39;t bother, frankly,
because on the few occasions it&#39;s effective

its main purpose is to make the game marginally
less interesting. I say &#39;marginally&#39; because

the core combat is only slightly more engaging
than clicking a single dialogue option and

getting the subsequent tense diplomatic negotiation
summarised for you by the narrator. The combat

is like a paddling pool full of refrigerator
parts and white bread - not much fun. And
shallow. And for babbies. And overcomplicated.

You&#39;ve got your one hand weapons and your
two hand weapons, which can be fully customised

with different hilts and blades and various
addons, customisable armour parts, ranged

weapons, combo attacks, magic attacks, parries,
ripostes, wedgies, holding them down and gobbing

on their face, and it all goes to waste because
the moment to moment action just doesn&#39;t have

any satisfying weight to it, it&#39;s just watching
bouncing furballs waving sticks around like

ewoks holding a rave inside a tumble dryer.
And then you realise your stamina comes back

way too fast so you might as well just spam
your favourite magic attack over and over

again like you&#39;re sick of babysitting and
it&#39;s the button that turns on Sesame Street.

In microcosm the combat displays the issue
that runs through the entire game - that it&#39;s

thrown too many ideas into the pile without
thinking about how it&#39;s going to fit them

all through the door. The story and mechanics
needed to be paced out better, or indeed at

all. I can&#39;t engage with the plot and none
of the mechanics are fun. There&#39;s no solid

core here to bring everything together. It&#39;s
like they kept adding stuff to a shish kebab

and then ran out of skewer so they started
hot gluing chunks of meat and bell pepper

to the end and needed to realise that there
are much more elegant ways to get someone
to leave your barbecue.
